Data Analysis

1. Introduction

AI-Enhanced Data Analysis for Research.

Why AI-based tools are transforming data analysis.

The idea of “analysis as conversation” — using AI to explore data, build models, and iterate quickly.

Positioning your MIDAS interface as a practical, low-barrier way for UM researchers to start.

2. Overview of the MIDAS Data Analysis Interface

What the interface does and what problems it solves.

Who it is designed for (researchers who don’t want to code from scratch / domain experts exploring models).

2.1 Workflow summary

Upload data → explore → preprocess → model → evaluate → export results

2.2 Key Features

  • Support for tabular datasets (CSV, Excel)

  • Automatic preprocessing, missing value handling, and feature engineering

  • Access to classical ML + AutoGluon deep learning models

  • Alignment with U-M privacy policy (no PHI uploads)

  • Exportable results, plots, and reproducible scripts

  • arXiv metadata datasets

  • Open fNIRS datasets

  • Structured vs unstructured

  • Licensing

  • Deidentification requirements

5. AutoML with AutoGluon

5.1 Why AutoGluon?

  • Strong baselines

  • Great for small/medium tabular datasets

  • Stacking/ensembling

  • Minimal code

5.2 Supported Tasks

  • Classification

  • Regression

  • Time-series forecasting

  • Multimodal

5.3 Using AutoGluon in the Interface

  • Presets

  • Hyperparameter tuning

  • Leaderboard

  • Feature importance

  • Model export

5.4 Practical Tips

  • Proper splits

  • Avoid leakage

  • Interpretability

  • When AutoML is insufficient

6. Model Evaluation & Reporting

6.1 Metrics

  • Accuracy, F1, ROC-AUC

  • MAPE, MASE

6.2 Interpretation Tools

  • Feature importance

  • PDP plots

  • Error analysis

  • Model files

  • Tracking preprocessing steps

8. Ethical & Policy Considerations

  • Do NOT upload PHI

  • Use synthetic data

  • U-M governance alignment

  • Responsible open science

  • U-M ecosystem supports responsible use
